QuestionTxt: Do you have a favorable or unfavorable opinion of Mitt Romney?
SampleDesc: National adults who watched the debate
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline
StudyNote: The sample included 362 interviews among landline respondents and 68 interviews among cell phone respondents.  The respondents were first interviewed as part of a national sample on September 28-October 2, 2012, and the respondent indicated they planned to watch the debate and were willing to be re-interviewed after the debate.

QuestionTxt: Next, I'd like you to rate...(Mitt) Romney on a scale.  If you have a favorable opinion of him, name a number between plus one and plus five--where a plus five is the highest position indicating you have a very favorable opinion of him.  If you have an unfavorable opinion, name a number between minus one and minus five where minus five is the lowest position--indicating you have a very unfavorable opinion of him.  How far up or down the scale would you rate...Romney?

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'm going to mention some people and groups in the news recently. For each, please tell me if your feelings are very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable. If you don't know enough to answer, just say so.)...Mitt Romney, former Republican nominee for president of the United States
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted by landline and cell phones. Questions asked June 13 about the Orlando mass shooting included 258 respondents from the main sample and 150 from a supplemental sample.

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization. If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Mitt Romney...Give...Mitt Romney a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...Mitt Romney, or have you never heard of...Mitt Romney?
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2008 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2012 election or they already voted.

QuestionTxt: Has what you have seen, read, or heard in the past couple of weeks about Mitt Romney and his (2012) campaign for president given you a more favorable impression of him or a less favorable impression of him?  If you have not seen, read, or heard anything in the past couple of weeks please just say so.
StudyNote:
The sample included some respondents who use a cell phone only. This note explains the method and result of the Likely Voter (LV) process for the NBC
News/The Wall Street Journal 2012 polling.  The LV methodology was applied beginning in June 2012 and data was reported publicly starting in
September 2012.  How NBC-WSJ Defines a 2012 Likely Voter 1. Age 18-24 has to be %8-10 interest in election, 2. Age 25-29 has to be two of three:
a. 8-10 interest in election; b. 2008 voter; or, c. 2010 voter.  3. Age 30+ has to be two of three: a. 9-10 interest in election; b. 2008 voter; or, c. 2010 voter.
With those restrictions, LVs should be 82%-84% of registered voters.  If the Likely Voter sample is higher than 84%, we narrow the definition further, allowing only those likely voters who say they are absolutely certain to vote or already voted to qualify through the screener.  The link to this methodology is 
http://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/likelyvotermemo.pdf .

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't know enough to say)...Mitt Romney
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (I would like to read you a list of names of people and groups and have you tell me, for each one, whether you've heard of that person or group and, if so, whether you have a favorable or unfavorable opinion of them.  If you haven't heard of the person or group, just say so.)...Mitt Romney...(If Favorable/Unfavorable, ask:) Would that be very favorable/unfavorable or just somewhat favorable/unfavorable?
SampleDesc: National likely voters including an oversample of battleground state voters
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted by landline and cell phones.  Likely voters are registered voters who said they are absolutely certain/very likely/somewhat likely to vote in the 2012 election.  The survey included 1000 likely voters including an oversample to reach a total of 462 voters in 12 battleground states: Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national likely voters population.

Results were weighted to be representative of a national likely voters population.

QuestionTxt: Please rate your feelings toward Mitt Romney. Is your overall impression of him...Extremely favorable, favorable, somewhat favorable, neither favorable nor unfavorable, somewhat unfavorable, unfavorable, extremely unfavorable
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether increased conservatism in response to the growth of an outgroup, as previously observed in non-Hispanic White populations, is also observed in racial minority groups. A total of 620 respondents participated. Respondents were randomly assigned to read one of two press releases from the U.S. Census Bureau describing either the growth of non-White populations in the U.S. or the growth in geographic mobility. All respondents were surveyed on their concerns about the current state of the societal system/American culture, feelings toward non-Hispanic Whites, Asians, Hispanics, and Blacks, policy preferences related to immigration and national defense, and political ideology. This allowed for comparison of White and racial minority subgroup reactions to the growth of a minority outgroup.
SubPopulation: Asked of treatment group, respondents who read a US Census press release on the growth of minority populations (n=303)
SurveySponsor: Craig, Maureen and Jennifer A. Richeson
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote: Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Mitt Romney...Give...Mitt Romney a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. SurveySponsor: Democracy Corps; Women's Voices Women Vote
SourceDoc: Democracy Corps/Women's Voices. Women Vote Poll
SampleDesc: Likely voters in Republican/Democratic held battleground districts
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2008 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2012 election.  The survey included 1000 likley voters in 56 Republican-held battleground districts and 500 likely voters in 23 Democratic-held battleground districts.  Respondents were interviewed on landline telephones and cell phones.

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold.  You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Mitt Romney...Give...Mitt Romney a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...Mitt Romney, or have you never heard of...Mitt Romney?
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2008 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2012 election.

QuestionTxt: Now we would like your views on some political leaders and groups.  Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable....Mitt Romney
SourceDoc: Public Religion Research Institute Jewish Values Survey
SampleDesc: Self-identified Jewish adults in the United States
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  Only self-identified Jewish Americans were interviewed.  The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  Only self-identified Jewish Americans were interviewed.  The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to be representative of a national adult Jewish American sample.  The survey was funded by the Nathan Cummings Foundation.

QuestionTxt: Please rate your feelings toward Mitt Romney. Is your overall impression of him...Extremely favorable, favorable, somewhat favorable, neither favorable nor unfavorable, somewhat unfavorable, unfavorable, extremely unfavorable
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether increased conservatism in response to the growth of an outgroup, as previously observed in non-Hispanic White populations, is also observed in racial minority groups. A total of 620 respondents participated. Respondents were randomly assigned to read one of two press releases from the U.S. Census Bureau describing either the growth of non-White populations in the U.S. or the growth in geographic mobility. All respondents were surveyed on their concerns about the current state of the societal system/American culture, feelings toward non-Hispanic Whites, Asians, Hispanics, and Blacks, policy preferences related to immigration and national defense, and political ideology. This allowed for comparison of White and racial minority subgroup reactions to the growth of a minority outgroup.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents who read a US Census press release on the increase in geographic mobility (n=317)
SurveySponsor: Craig, Maureen and Jennifer A. Richeson
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote: Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: If you learned that Mitt Romney opposes the current health care law signed into law by Barack Obama (March 2010) that institutes requiring nearly all Americans to either have or purchase health insurance, but as governor supported and signed into law a bill that had similar requirements for Massachusetts--would this make you feel more favorable about him, less favorable about him or would it not make a difference in your opinion of him one way or the other?
SampleDesc: National adult including an oversample of GOP primary voters
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline
StudyNote: An oversample of 81 Republican Primary voters was included.  The sample included 200 respondents who use a cell phone only.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult population.

QuestionTxt: Now I would like to read you the names of several other individuals who have been mentioned in the news recently.  For each one, please tell me whether you have heard of that person and if so, whether you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of them.  If you do not recognize the name, just say so....Mitt Romney...(If Favorable/Unfavorable, ask:) Would that be a strongly favorable/unfavorable impression or just a somewhat favorable/unfavorable impression?
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who said they are somewhat/very/extremely likely to vote in 2008.

(Now I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold.  You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Mitt Romney...Give...Mitt Romney a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...Mitt Romney, or have you never heard of...Mitt Romney?
SubPopulation: Asked of Form B half sample
StudyNote: National likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election.  1017 of the respondents were asked all of the questions (long survey), 509 were asked a shorter version.  Results are from all 1526 respondents unless otherwise noted.

QuestionTxt: As you may know, the state of Massachusetts passed a health reform law in 2006 when Mitt Romney was the state's governor.  Given what you know about it, do you have a generally favorable or generally unfavorable opinion of the Massachusetts health reform law, or do you not know enough to say? (If Favorable/Unfavorable, ask:) Is that a very favorable/unfavorable or somewhat favorable/unfavorable opinion?
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline
StudyNote: 718 respondents were interviewed on a landline telephone, and 505 were interviewed on a cell phone, including 290 who had no landline telephone.
